content:
Jinhao Luo is a student of Master of Business Analytics at the Monash University. He is mainly learning data collection, data wrangling, data exploration, and relevant mathematics models to solve the data problem currently. In addition, R is the programming language he currently studying.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
  Download my resumé.
summary: Jinhao Luo is a student of Master of Business Analytics at the Monash University. He is mainly learning data collection, data wrangling, data exploration, and relevant mathematics models to solve the data problem currently.
title: Jinhao Luo

content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
IntroductionIwasaki and Grubaugh (2020) indicates that although Japan has a dense and aging population, it still reported low cases of COVID-19 infection in the first few months of the COVID-19 outbreak, compared with other countries. However, according to the latest COVID-19 report from the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan, Japan has experienced the second outbreak of COVID-19 from July 2020 (Ministry of Health and Welfare (2020)). And it is more serious than the first one. Therefore, this post will focus on the COVID-19 cases of Japan.
Data descriptionFor exploring the COVID-19 situations of Japan, the post has used the COVID-19 data from the package called coronavirus. This package is from the Github repository owned by Rami Krispin, which could find all information related to this package from Github. By glimpsing this data, there are 175055 observations and 7 variables. Based on the help page of the coronavirus package, Krispin and Byrnes (2020) indicate the variables are in the following table 1:
Table 1: Description of variables in coronavirus dataVariableClassDescriptiondateDateThe format of date is YYYY-MM-DDprovincecharacterName of province or state, if providedcountrycharacterName of country or regionlatnumericLatitude of center of geographic regionlongnumericLongitude of center of geographic regiontypecharacterType of cases (confirmed, death, recovered)casesintegerNumber of cases on given dateBecause this post will focus on the cases of Japan, the filter function will be used to filter the data which makes the data only include Japan’s cases. Besides, because the types of COVID-19 cases are all contained in the same column, the function call pivot_wider will be applied to change the position of type as a variable rather than value.
Data story.table.table-striped.table-hover, .table thead th {font-size: 5px;}Table 2: Summary table of COVID-19 cases in Japanyearmonthmonthly confirmedmonthly deathmonthly recoveredcumulative confirmedcumulative deathcumulative recovered2020115011501202022306312456322020320106139222556742420204120294142036142844812460202052467417118821675189814342202061864742116186159721645820207176193683163623410082477420208321622903156468396129856338In order to explore the COVID-19 situations of Japan and identify the second outbreak situation, a summary table has been generated to support the following explanation. Table 2 indicates the monthly cases and cumulative cases of Japan from the first patient have been confirmed to the end of August 2020. Based on table 2, there were little cases in the first three month in Japan, which were only 2255 total cases and just account for 3.3% of the total confirmed cases. The first outbreak happened in April of 2020, which reported 12029 cases increased in this month, and the total cases have jumped to 14284 cases. The confirmed cases of April have increased 433.44% compared with the first three month total confirmed cases. Fortunately, the monthly confirmed cases of May and June all gradually decreased, and the total confirmed cases have slowly increased. However, May has reported the highest mortality among the eight months. There were 417 death cases in May, and it even three cases higher than that of the first outbreak, which was 414 cases. The reason might because the outbreak in April resulted in high confirmed cases so that led to the highest mortality in May. But, fortunately, the monthly recovered cases in May was 11882, and the cumulative recovered cases have reached to 14342, which accounted for 85.62% of the cumulative confirmed cases. And the recovery rate of June has reached to 88.41%.
However, because of the gradual return to works or the consciousness of defenses for COVID-19 of people may already be worn down. Japan also experienced the same second COVID-19 outbreak like other countries. The monthly confirmed cases of July have recorded at 17619, which increased 845.23% over June. Furthermore, August has recorded the highest monthly confirmed cases within eight months, which were 32162 cases. Such high monthly cases have contributed to the dramatic increase in cumulative confirmed cases of August which were 68396. And the monthly confirmed rate of August has accounted for almost a half among the total cases in eight months, which was 47.02%. Fortunately, there were only 36 death cases and 290 death cases in July and August, respectively. In addition, the recovered cases in July and August were also high, which were 8316 and 31564 cases, respectively. Finally, there are 82.37% of patients have reported as recovery at the end of August. That should be good news for Japan.
Interactive tableFor helping the readers to better realise the COVID-19 situation of Japan. An interactive table has been created for the readers to explore the data of COVID-19 in Japan. Please refer to the following Figure 1.
{"x":{"url":"/post/COVID_19_JAPAN/COVID-19-Japan_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_DT-table.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 1: The interactive table of COVID-19 situations in JapanConclusionMany countries have experienced the second COVID-19 outbreak nowadays, as well as Japan. Everyone still needs to keep their consciousness of defense this pandemic. Furthermore, hoping the novel coronavirus vaccine will come out as soon as possible, as well as there is no increasing trend of confirmed cases in Japan.
AcknowledgementFor the reproducibility of this post, You can find the relevant information of coronavirus package in this Github repository. In addition, the versions of R and packages which used in this post would be listed in the following.
The programming language used to write the data story of COVID-19 in Japan is R (4.0.2) (R Core Team 2020). Following packages has been included in our scripts:
package coronavirus (0.3.0.9000) (Krispin and Byrnes 2020),package tidyverse (1.3.0) (Wickham et al. 2019),package kableExtra (1.1.0) (Zhu 2019),package tibble (3.0.3) (Müller and Wickham 2020),package lubridate (1.7.9) (Grolemund and Wickham 2011),package widgetframe (0.3.1) (Karambelkar 2017),package DT (0.15) (Xie, Cheng, and Tan 2020),package htmltools (0.5.0) (Cheng et al. 2020)ReferencesCheng, Joe, Carson Sievert, Winston Chang, Yihui Xie, and Jeff Allen. 2020. Htmltools: Tools for Html. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=htmltools.
Grolemund, Garrett, and Hadley Wickham. 2011. “Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate.” Journal of Statistical Software 40 (3): 1–25. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v40/i03/.
Iwasaki, Akiko, and Nathan D Grubaugh. 2020. “Why Does Japan Have so Few Cases of Covid-19?” EMBO Molecular Medicine 12 (5): e12481.
Karambelkar, Bhaskar. 2017. Widgetframe: ’Htmlwidgets’ in Responsive ’Iframes’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=widgetframe.
Krispin, Rami, and Jarrett Byrnes. 2020. Coronavirus: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus Covid-19 (2019-nCoV) Dataset. https://github.com/RamiKrispin/coronavirus.
Ministry of Health, Labour, and Japan Welfare. 2020. “Changes in the Number of Individuals Requiring Hospital Treatment, Critically Ill Individuals, and Newly Reported Cases Etc.” https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000666371.pdf.
Müller, Kirill, and Hadley Wickham. 2020. Tibble: Simple Data Frames. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tibble.
R Core Team. 2020. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org/.
Wickham, Hadley, Mara Averick, Jennifer Bryan, Winston Chang, Lucy D’Agostino McGowan, Romain François, Garrett Grolemund, et al. 2019. “Welcome to the tidyverse.” Journal of Open Source Software 4 (43): 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686.
Xie, Yihui, Joe Cheng, and Xianying Tan. 2020. DT: A Wrapper of the Javascript Library ’Datatables’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=DT.
Zhu, Hao. 2019. KableExtra: Construct Complex Table with ’Kable’ and Pipe Syntax. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=kableExtra.
summary: This post will explore the situation of COVID-19 in Japan
title: COVID-19 situations of Japan

title: An example preprint / working paper

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

title: An example conference paper

content:
COVID-19 situations of Japan This post is used for exploring the situations of COVID-19 in Japan.
Data source The data come from the coronavirus package in Github of Rami Krispin. You can browse the related information of coronavirus package by this link.
You have two ways to download the coronavirus package.
CRAN version Try the command:
install.packages(“coronavirus”)
Github version Try the command:
install.packages(“devtools”)
devtools::install_github(“RamiKrispin/coronavirus”)
P.S. You need to install the devtools package first, if you already have this package, please ignore it.
Data refresh To refresh the data, please try:
library(coronavirus)
update_dataset()
Or you can use the Covid19R project data standard format to pull the data, please try:
new_object <- refresh_coronavirus_jhu()
P.S. You can rename the new_object
summary:

Data source The data come from the coronavirus package in Github of Rami Krispin. You can browse the related information of coronavirus package by this link.
